author: DREW ZIMMERMAN drew.zimmerman@lee.net
title: McLean County accepts a $200K EPA grant for energy efficiency programs
text: BLOOMINGTON — McLean County will be using $200,000 awarded by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to perform [energy efficiency upgrades](https://pantagraph.com/news/local/government-politics/mclean-county-adopts-green-energy-contract-for-electricity-usage/article_8333d8b4-21d2-11ee-9603-d752f0eed781.html) at its health department building and develop a long-term strategic plan for energy use. The County Board on Thursday approved a grant agreement for the funding, which is part of the Energy Efficiency and Conservation Block Grant program. The program is meant to support units of local government in their development of strategies to [reduce energy use](https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/govt-and-politics/new-illinois-state-energy-project-standards-welcomed-by-some-resisted-by-others/article_936c9518-a96e-11ed-bb60-a70a4975919d.html) and fossil fuel emissions. People are also reading… Board member Jim Soeldner said half of the money will go to the installation of LED fixtures and associated controls in the health department building at 200 W Front St., Bloomington. Based on the results of a 2023 energy audit, the county determined several other energy efficiency upgrades at the health department that would meet the program's funding and timeline requirements, including a decentralized domestic hot water system. The other half will be used by the Ecology Action Center in Normal to finalize a study on the best management of the county's future energy use. "They have a bunch of different programs going on but there's a main program right now where they're doing a big research study to see how we can best do that in the county," Soeldner said. According to the grant agreement, the energy plan and building upgrades must be completed by June 30, 2026. The county has taken several other steps to reduce its energy emissions. Commercial property owners in the county are eligible for the Commercial Property Assessed Clean Energy, or [C-PACE program](https://pantagraph.com/news/local/government-politics/mclean-county-joins-loan-program-for-energy-efficient-projects/article_07e70930-19eb-11ef-8d7f-177a38a15d88.html), which offers financing through eligible providers on a variety of clean energy projects such as heating and cooling systems and solar panels.
